Dr. Antonio Logoluso, Italian
consul to Baltimore from his
majesty, the King of Italy, will deliver a lecture in the Civil Engineering Building on March 6th at
8:15 P. M. His subject will be,
"The Labor Question in Italy under the Fascist Regime". This is
the first of a series of lectures sponsored monthly, by the Baltimore
Chapter of the Intercollegiate Italian Club of America. The club was
recently organized and has chapters
in several principal cities of the
United States. The chapter in
Baltimore consists of approximately
fifty members, representing the
University of Maryland, University of Baltimore, Loyola College
and Johns Hopkins University. At
a later date, Dr. Kent Greenfield of
Hopkins will speak. These lectures
are open to the public.

EDITORIALS
CO-OPERATION?
THROUGHOUT the present year the complete lack of co-operation
± on the part of the members of the senior class has unnecessarily
complicated the work of the Hullabaloo staff on this year's annual.
Although ample notice was given, a great number of the members
of the class failed to make appointments for individual photographs
in November. Because of this, it was necessary that the photographers
spend considerable time in taking individual photographs when they
returned to the campus to take group pictures. All of the senior
statistics have not been turned in as yet in spite of the fact that it is
essential to have these before starting on senior write-ups for the
books. If these are not turned in at once, it will be impossible to .put
the Hullabaloo out on time. Yesterday slips were placed in post
office boxes for election to the Hall of Fame. We hope that they will
be turned in within a month.
One would think that members of the class who do no work on
the year-book themselves would at least have enough interest in their
annual to fill out statistics and to make appointments to be photographed. But, as we have said before, we have yet to find anything
in which any number of Hopkins men are vitally interested.

THIS MATTER OF INITIATIONS
THE following editorial appeared recently in The Lafayette, undergraduate publication at Lafayette College.
"Customarily, editors of collegiate literary organs launch tirades
against the initiation systems clung to by fraternities. It is refreshing to
note that, at Lafayette, the prevalence of inane horseplay is diminishing in that respect. Fraternities are coming to realize that the humorous aspect of seeing cattle tethered about the campus is losing its
freshness. They are beginning to see that the process of admitting
a man to lifelong affiliation with an organization can be just as
effective without the clowning.
"There is still room for improvement in that the realization has
not yet come about that it is harmful scholastically both to the individual and the group to allow the period of the initiation of the
neophytes to drag over a period of a week or ten days. At this time
of the year the professors are taxed with the problem of poor attendance and poorer recitation. Mediocre work at the commencement of
a term means a poor foundation in the subject and carries with it the
difficulty of accomplishing highly efficient work later in the spring.
At several colleges the process of pledging a man and admitting him
into the bonds of brotherhood takes no more than three days. 'Undoubtedly this is more feasible where second term or second year
rushing is the rule. However, steps toward shortening initiations
might well be taken without such conditions existing. Certainly such
a change would not be viewed with alarm by the faculty".
Although at the Hopkins we are not troubled with initiations
lasting over a period of a week, the above arguments may be advanced
for the complete abolishment of informal initiations—a move that we
firmly favor and believe that will be accomplished in the near future.

Mr. Bullock says the system is
excellent, but that he would rather
use "pass" or "fail."
Dr. Roulston claims that he was
misquoted or misinterpreted. Apparently, he resents the fact that
the reporter revealed, with good intentions, that it was learned from
his students that he used, in many
instances, variations in the S. It
may be stated here that it was explained later that the "variations"
consisted of several S minuses
which he gave to prevent the official
recording of F grades to those students who were "doubtful" and
Dr. Roulston desired to allow to go
on in second half work.
Dr. Lane, by error of rewriting,
was quoted as being in favor of
five marks. On the contrary, Dr.
Lane uses five grades in marking
his weekly quizzes, but advocates
the use of pass and fail, for practical purposes.
A letter received from Dr. Cohen
reveals his surprise at finding himself classified as among those not
adhering to the new grading system.
He said:
"It was news to me to learn that I use
numbers as equivalents to H and S. I had

Professor of Comparative Law At the University of Hamburg, Germany, To Begin Series of Five
Talks Tomorrow
Dr. Albrecht Mendelssohn Bartholdy, professor of comparative
law and director of the Institute of
Foreign Politics at the University
of Hamburg, Germany, has been
selected to deliver the James
Schouler Foundation lectures on
history and political science according to a recent announcement of
Dr. John H. Lotane, professor of
American history.
Dr. Bartholdy, will give the first
of his series of five talks tomorrow
afternoon in C. E. 120 at 5 P. M.
The four other lectures are scheduled for March 6, 9, 11 and 13,
at the same time and place.

'345°

To Lecture on Africa

All five of the lectures will be on
Africa as related to international
affairs. He will deal with mandates in central Africa especially.
Dr. Bartholdy is a great-great
grandson of Moses Mendelssohn,
the famous philanthropist, and is
a grandson of Felix Mendelssohn,

the composer. The visitor was one
of the two editors of the archives
of the German Foreign Office and
specializes in the field of modern
European relations. He lectured
at the Williams College Institute of
Politics in 1926, and in 1927 at
Harvard. At this latter institution,
he was awarded an honorary degree. This was the first one given
by that University after the World
War.
Founded Magazine

Last winter, at the opening of
the new social science building of
the university of Chicago, he was
one of the principal speakers. Last
year he founded a magazine, the
Hamburg Anierika Post, printed in
both German and English. He also
is establishing in connection with
his department at Hamburg, a library of American law. He has
been a member of various German
and international commissions on
governmental affairs and was one
of the judges of the tribunal on interpretation of the Dawes plan.

Washington, D. C.—A recent
survey by the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce for the Year
Book of 1931 shows a large increase in the number of aviation
courses in the various colleges over
the country. Colleges are becoming
increasingly more air-minded and
boast more students, more teachers
and more courses than in previous
years.
A thousand more students than
last year are studying aviation in
colleges and more than one-third
of these are taking four-year
courses that will lead to a special
bachelor's or master's degree in
aviation. Not only are more students studying aviation, but more
colleges are offering courses in response to a growing demand, the
report reveals. Seventy-four colleges now have courses of some
sort in aviation as against 61 for
last year.
Just as in medicine or engineering, students may now take graduate courses in aviation. *Fourteen
different colleges now offer graduate courses. These institutions offer
full four-year courses, leading to
degrees of bachelor of science in
aeronautical engineering , or air
transportation, and gr aduat e
courses which give degrees of master of science in aeronautical engineering or doctor of philosophy.
—(N.S.F.A.)

Kansas University Has
SelfStyled Snoopers
'Group of Eight,' In Anonymous Letter, States It'll Care for Liquor
Enforcement

Lawrence, Kan.—An unknown
committee has taken the "responsibility" for liquor enforcement at
the University of Kansas. A letter to this effect was received by
Kenneth Meuser, president of the
Men's Student Council; Prof.
Henry Werner, men's student adviser, and the Daily Kansan. It
follows:
"To whom it may concern:
"In reply to the so-called clearance resolutions passed by the men's
Pan-Hellenic and Student Councils
'clearing' the drinking problem on
this campus, we, a group of eight
students with the co-operation of
an outside group, are taking it upon
ourselves to see that these promises
are fulfilled.
"Working among the student
body we hope to gather sufficient
information to rid the campus of its
student drinkers and bootleggers
and to see that your diplomatic
`lankets' are not idle threats.
"We are forwarding a copy of
this letter to the men's student adviser, the president of the Men's
Student Council, and to the University Daily Kansan.
"Watch your step,
"The Group of Eight."
College officials refused to comment on the letter today, saying
that anonymous contributions of
this sort were usually of little importance.

Prospects for this year's track
team seem brighter than they've
been in many seasons. Last Thursday first practice was held and a
squad of approximately sixty candidates turned out. Of this group
a majority have been on the squad
in past seasons. Besides last year's
regulars several men who were previously ineligible are now able to
compete.
Positions Open To Able Men

The greatest opportunities for
new men lie in the long-distance
events and in the hurdles. Kelly
and Emerson, both one and two
and Schiedt, Hermilers are god;'
shey and Stafford, hurdlers, also
have graduated. 'However this
doesn't mean that other aspirants
shouldn't try out. Positions are always open to the best men.
Coach Hambleton intends to
make use of every possible candidate. Plans are being made to
build up a schedule for a junior
varsity team to compete against local prep schools. Likewise, hAndicap events will be held among the
members of the squad, and those
scoring the highest number of
points will be awarded medals.
These events not only offer opportunities for experience but also
give the newcomer a chance to discover those events in which he is
particularly adept.
Squad Gets New Material
Fortunately the athletic depart-

ment has supplied the squad with a
reasonable amount of new material.
As a result, practically every candidate has been supplied with some
necessary facilities.

in several principal cities of the
United States. The chapter in
Baltimore consists of approximately
fifty members, representing the
University of Maryland, University of Baltimore, Loyola College

a later date, Dr. Kent Greenfield of
Hopkins will speak. These lectures
are open to the public.

EDITORIALS
CO-OPERATION?
THROUGHOUT the present year the complete lack of co-operation
± on the part of the members of the senior class has unnecessarily
complicated the work of the Hullabaloo staff on this year's annual.
Although ample notice was given, a great number of the members
of the class failed to make appointments for individual photographs
in November. Because of this, it was necessary that the photographers
spend considerable time in taking individual photographs when they
returned to the campus to take group pictures. All of the senior
statistics have not been turned in as yet in spite of the fact that it is
essential to have these before starting on senior write-ups for the
books. If these are not turned in at once, it will be impossible to .put
the Hullabaloo out on time. Yesterday slips were placed in post
office boxes for election to the Hall of Fame. We hope that they will
be turned in within a month.
One would think that members of the class who do no work on
the year-book themselves would at least have enough interest in their
annual to fill out statistics and to make appointments to be photographed. But, as we have said before, we have yet to find anything
in which any number of Hopkins men are vitally interested.

THIS MATTER OF INITIATIONS
THE following editorial appeared recently in The Lafayette, undergraduate publication at Lafayette College.
"Customarily, editors of collegiate literary organs launch tirades
against the initiation systems clung to by fraternities. It is refreshing to
note that, at Lafayette, the prevalence of inane horseplay is diminishing in that respect. Fraternities are coming to realize that the humorous aspect of seeing cattle tethered about the campus is losing its
freshness. They are beginning to see that the process of admitting
a man to lifelong affiliation with an organization can be just as
effective without the clowning.
"There is still room for improvement in that the realization has
not yet come about that it is harmful scholastically both to the individual and the group to allow the period of the initiation of the
neophytes to drag over a period of a week or ten days. At this time
of the year the professors are taxed with the problem of poor attendance and poorer recitation. Mediocre work at the commencement of
a term means a poor foundation in the subject and carries with it the
difficulty of accomplishing highly efficient work later in the spring.
At several colleges the process of pledging a man and admitting him
into the bonds of brotherhood takes no more than three days. 'Undoubtedly this is more feasible where second term or second year
rushing is the rule. However, steps toward shortening initiations
might well be taken without such conditions existing. Certainly such
a change would not be viewed with alarm by the faculty".
Although at the Hopkins we are not troubled with initiations
lasting over a period of a week, the above arguments may be advanced
for the complete abolishment of informal initiations—a move that we
firmly favor and believe that will be accomplished in the near future.

Mr. Bullock says the system is
excellent, but that he would rather
use "pass" or "fail."
Dr. Roulston claims that he was
misquoted or misinterpreted. Apparently, he resents the fact that
the reporter revealed, with good intentions, that it was learned from
his students that he used, in many
instances, variations in the S. It
may be stated here that it was explained later that the "variations"
consisted of several S minuses
which he gave to prevent the official
recording of F grades to those students who were "doubtful" and
Dr. Roulston desired to allow to go
on in second half work.
Dr. Lane, by error of rewriting,
was quoted as being in favor of
five marks. On the contrary, Dr.
Lane uses five grades in marking
his weekly quizzes, but advocates
the use of pass and fail, for practical purposes.
A letter received from Dr. Cohen
reveals his surprise at finding himself classified as among those not
adhering to the new grading system.
He said:
"It was news to me to learn that I use
numbers as equivalents to H and S. I had
hoped to impress him (the reporter- with
the fact the use of numerical grades, thus
giving a certain fixed value to a more or
less estimate of a man's work, has always
seemed unsatisfactory, and that I, for one,
was very glad to be relieved from having
to do this."

Professor of Comparative Law At the University of Hamburg, Germany, To Begin Series of Five
Talks Tomorrow
Dr. Albrecht Mendelssohn Bartholdy, professor of comparative
law and director of the Institute of
Foreign Politics at the University
of Hamburg, Germany, has been
selected to deliver the James
Schouler Foundation lectures on
history and political science according to a recent announcement of
Dr. John H. Lotane, professor of
American history.
Dr. Bartholdy, will give the first
of his series of five talks tomorrow
afternoon in C. E. 120 at 5 P. M.
The four other lectures are scheduled for March 6, 9, 11 and 13,
at the same time and place.

'345°

To Lecture on Africa

All five of the lectures will be on
Africa as related to international
affairs. He will deal with mandates in central Africa especially.
Dr. Bartholdy is a great-great
grandson of Moses Mendelssohn,
the famous philanthropist, and is
a grandson of Felix Mendelssohn,

been a member of various German
and international commissions on
governmental affairs and was one
of the judges of the tribunal on interpretation of the Dawes plan.

Washington, D. C.—A recent
survey by the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce for the Year
Book of 1931 shows a large increase in the number of aviation
courses in the various colleges over
the country. Colleges are becoming
increasingly more air-minded and
boast more students, more teachers
and more courses than in previous
years.
A thousand more students than
last year are studying aviation in
colleges and more than one-third
of these are taking four-year
courses that will lead to a special
bachelor's or master's degree in
aviation. Not only are more students studying aviation, but more
colleges are offering courses in response to a growing demand, the
report reveals. Seventy-four colleges now have courses of some
sort in aviation as against 61 for
last year.
Just as in medicine or engineering, students may now take graduate courses in aviation. *Fourteen
different colleges now offer graduate courses. These institutions offer
full four-year courses, leading to
degrees of bachelor of science in
aeronautical engineering , or air
transportation, and gr aduat e
courses which give degrees of master of science in aeronautical engineering or doctor of philosophy.
—(N.S.F.A.)

Long regarded with misgiving by
apprehensive Public Speaking Students, the banquets at which
each student is required to deliver
an after-dinner speech have been
definitely arranged for. The Public Speaking Committee has decided
that each of the five sections will
have its banquet on some night of
the week of May 11-17. Efforts are
being made to secure a speaker and
musical entertainment for each evening. The Blue and Gray Inn,
North Avenue, near St. Paul, will
be the scene of festivities.

Lawrence, Kan.—An unknown
committee has taken the "responsibility" for liquor enforcement at
the University of Kansas. A letter to this effect was received by
Kenneth Meuser, president of the
Men's Student Council; Prof.
Henry Werner, men's student adviser, and the Daily Kansan. It
follows:
"To whom it may concern:
"In reply to the so-called clearance resolutions passed by the men's
Pan-Hellenic and Student Councils
'clearing' the drinking problem on
this campus, we, a group of eight
students with the co-operation of
an outside group, are taking it upon
ourselves to see that these promises
are fulfilled.
"Working among the student
body we hope to gather sufficient
information to rid the campus of its
student drinkers and bootleggers
and to see that your diplomatic
`lankets' are not idle threats.
"We are forwarding a copy of
this letter to the men's student adviser, the president of the Men's
Student Council, and to the University Daily Kansan.
"Watch your step,
"The Group of Eight."
College officials refused to comment on the letter today, saying
that anonymous contributions of
this sort were usually of little importance.

Prospects for this year's track
team seem brighter than they've
been in many seasons. Last Thursday first practice was held and a
squad of approximately sixty candidates turned out. Of this group
a majority have been on the squad
in past seasons. Besides last year's
regulars several men who were previously ineligible are now able to
compete.
Positions Open To Able Men

The greatest opportunities for
new men lie in the long-distance
events and in the hurdles. Kelly
and Emerson, both one and two
and Schiedt, Hermilers are god;'
shey and Stafford, hurdlers, also
have graduated. 'However this
doesn't mean that other aspirants
shouldn't try out. Positions are always open to the best men.
Coach Hambleton intends to
make use of every possible candidate. Plans are being made to
build up a schedule for a junior
varsity team to compete against local prep schools. Likewise, hAndicap events will be held among the
members of the squad, and those
scoring the highest number of
points will be awarded medals.
These events not only offer opportunities for experience but also
give the newcomer a chance to discover those events in which he is
particularly adept.
Squad Gets New Material
Fortunately the athletic depart-

ment has supplied the squad with a
reasonable amount of new material.
As a result, practically every candidate has been supplied with some
necessary facilities.
